Radiant floor heating (RFH) is an advanced technology that can couple with renewable low-temperature sources and improve occupant thermal comfort. However, due to the large thermal inertia, the conventional control strategies based on heuristic rules have difficulty handling a room temperature response to changes in weather or set-points. Because of the excellent coping ability, model predictive control (MPC) has aroused increasing attention as a promising solution to manage RFH. This research is focused on the MPC scheme for RFH systems, especially large-scale RFH systems with hydraulic coupling. First, we develop a novel control-oriented thermodynamic model for an RFH system. A new calculating method for the floor surface temperature is adopted to avoid defining the thermal resistance and thermal capacity of the virtual core temperature layer, and the heat transfer along water flow and weather elements like solar radiation and wind are considered. Then an experiment is conducted to validate that the accuracy can be adequate for the prediction of MPC. Next, we design a distributed MPC scheme for RFH systems with hydraulic coupling. A supply reset rule for central equipment is improved, and a hierarchical optimization algorithm is proposed to implement the distributed MPC scheme. Then a simulation test is carried out with results showing that the scheme can achieve hydraulic decoupling between occupants, thus avoiding room temperature fluctuations and decreasing the root-mean-square error by 0.24 °C. An appropriate supply set-point is recommended that meets thermal comfort demands with minimum energy consumption. 3D Three-dimensional 1 Introduction Heating in a residential building is known to be energy-consuming and costly. According to statistics, residential heating energy consumption in China accounts for approximately 34% of the total building operation energy consumption in the country [1]. Thus, residential space heating offers a large amount of potential for energy savings and cost reduction [2]. Radiant floor heating (RFH) is an advanced technology, that is also known as a Thermally Activated Building System (TABS) and serves as an alternative to conventional convector heating or all-air systems with the aim of reducing the use of energy resources and improving occupant comfort [3]. In RFH systems, heat is supplied to building floors by circulating water through pipes embedded in the structure, and the heat is transferred between temperature-controlled radiant surfaces and other surfaces or the air via radiation or convection [3]. In previous research, the superior performance of RFH systems has been highlighted, such as coupling with renewable low-temperature heat sources, creating favorable thermal comfort conditions and shifting the peak load periods [3,4]. These benefits can be maximized with prediction-based optimal control. Previous research also reported challenges involving the control of radiant systems. Although “smart” thermostats have increasingly provided occupants with prerequisites for room temperature control and energy management [2], it is difficult to handle their large thermal inertia with conventional feedback control strategies to make the indoor air temperature respond to changes in the weather or set-points such as regulating the valve or changing the supply water temperature based on heuristic rules [3]. In recent years, as it is able to handle time-varying disturbances, wide operating constraints, and slow-moving processes with time delays, model predictive control (MPC) has been largely investigated as a popular class of control strategies for heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems [5]. Based on a prediction model and an optimization algorithm, MPC can make a systematic and flexible implementation decision to adjust the control commands dynamically while automatically satisfying the steady-state and dynamic components related to HVAC systems [3]. At each control time-step, based on future weather and desired thermal comfort, an open-loop optimization problem is solved over a finite horizon, and the first value in the optimal control trajectory is implemented in the system. In the next control time-step, a new optimization problem is formulated and solved with updated information about the weather and demands [3]. These excellent features offer a promising solution for the control of hydronic radiant systems (HRSs). In previous research, simulations and experimental implementations using MPC have been carried out to control and optimize HRSs. In 2019, Karava et al. introduced a smart operation strategy based on MPC to optimize the performance of hydronic radiant floor systems in office buildings. The strategy produced 34% cost savings and 16% energy consumption reduction compared to baseline feedback control [3]. In 2020, Soroush et al. provided an economic nonlinear MPC for multiple buildings connected to a heat pump with thermal and electrical storage [4]. The proposed algorithm economically distributed energy among the storage to ensure cost benefits and comfort satisfaction. In 2021, Li et al. designed an MPC controller for RFH with an air-source heat pump, and the operation results indicated that the response time was reduced by approximately 90 min, and 14.9% of energy consumption was saved compared to a PID (proportional-integral-derivative) controller [7]. Later, Li et al. also proposed an MPC strategy for radiant ceiling cooling systems to allow the system to be more robust and adaptive to external thermal disturbances such as solar radiation and ambient temperature [8]. The simulation results showed that MPC outperformed PID control with over 20% energy savings and a smaller overshoot error. After that, Saberi et al. presented MPC strategies to activate energy flexibility for zones with radiant heating systems in response to changes in electricity prices [9]. The developed control strategies aided greatly in enhancing the zone energy flexibility and minimizing the cost of electricity during the high-price and peak-demand periods while maintaining acceptable comfort conditions. In the same year, Yuan et al. proposed an adaptive MPC for a hybrid air-conditioning system using a radiant floor and all-air system to solve the heating supply control difficulties of a railway station [10]. The implementation of adaptive MPC improved indoor thermal comfort and reduced 22.2% of the energy consumption compared to PID control. The above research demonstrated that MPC has been arousing increasing interest among researchers as a promising solution for managing HRSs. Of course, although previous research highlighted the benefits of MPC for HRSs, the involved prediction model and optimization scheme still need continuous improvements for their successful deployment. The precise prediction of future behaviors is the key to determining optimal control actions in MPC. Thus, the prediction model is the backbone of MPC and the uniqueness of each system requires customized modeling, which is a major challenge that increases the engineering time and cost when applying model-based control strategies [9]. Due to intensive computational costs, two-dimensional or three-dimensional detailed models established with CFD (computational fluid dynamics) are only suitable for simulation analysis [11,12]. Hence, developing a low-order control-oriented thermodynamic model is important for the implementation of MPC for HRSs [9]. In previous research, the commonly adopted modeling techniques of MPC for HRSs included data-driven models and simplified physics-based models [10]. Karava et al. constructed a data-driven gray-box building model based on the state-space formulas including the temperature of the cavity, indoor air, concrete, slab surface and slab core [3]. The RMSEs (root-mean-square errors) of the model for the indoor air and the slab surface temperatures were 0.47 °C and 0.70 °C for the cooling season, and the corresponding RMSEs for the heating season were 1.02 °C and 1.09 °C. Xiao et al. developed a gray-box dynamic thermal model and represented it in a stochastic state-space form to predict the thermal dynamics of a room integrated with an underfloor heating system [13]. The RMSEs of the indoor air temperature and floor surface temperature for a TRNSYS model and gray-box model were 0.170 °C and 0.135 °C, respectively. The corresponding MAEs (mean absolute errors) were 0.118 °C and 0.099 °C, respectively. Afram et al. developed RC (thermal resistance and thermal capacity) thermal network gray-box models for residential HVAC systems consisting of multi-zone AHU (air handling unit) and RFH systems [14]. Soroush et al. provided a control-oriented model of a time-varying continuous nonlinear system formed by radiant floor buildings connected to an air-to-water heat pump, and they verified that the linear time-varying MPC outperformd successive linear MPC and achieved a performance close to that of nonlinear MPC [15]. The above research demonstrated that compared with the black-box modeling method, the data-driven gray-box modeling technique had better generalization capabilities based on prior knowledge of thermal features and valid measured data [10]. On the other hand, there is also abundant research concerning physics-based lumped RC models. Li et al. developed a fast high-fidelity reduced-order model to accurately characterize the dynamic thermal performance of an RFH system by applying the balanced truncation method [16]. The experimental tests demonstrated that the MAEs of the indoor air, floor surface and return water temperatures were 1.27 °C, 0.08 °C, and 3.19 °C, and their corresponding RMSEs were 1.88 °C, 0.41 °C, and 4.19 °C, respectively. In the same year, Li et al. established a state-space model for MPC for a radiant ceiling cooling system to gain better thermal comfort and efficient energy savings [8]. The MAEs of the zone air and radiant ceiling surface temperatures reached 0.15 °C and 0.11 °C, respectively, while their corresponding RMSEs were 0.24 °C and 0.55 °C. Saberi developed a second-order thermal network model for a test room equipped with HRSs and calibrated it with experimental operating data [9]. The well-calibrated model could capture thermal dynamics of the test room with an error of less than 0.45 °C. The above research indicated that through calibration, physics-based lumped RC thermal network models could also obtain good accuracy. Moreover, compared with data-driven models, physics-based models perform more robustly because their parameters are easy to interpret from the physical perspective, and they still show effectiveness for the operating conditions that are not covered by the validation data [9], which is important to carry out the MPC strategy for a residential building with RFH systems. However, in the previous research, a mean water temperature in the pipes was mostly assumed, and the variation of the water temperature along pipes was neglected [3,4,10,13,15]. Some significant thermal disturbances such as solar radiation and wind might also have been ignored [4,9,15], which causes rooms to be frequently overheated during the daytime. Additionally, to simplify the two-dimensional heat flow in a slab to one-dimensional heat flow, the star-type RC-network model with a virtual core temperature layer in the centerline of pipes embedded in the slab [17–20], which was initially put forward in 1999 [21], has commonly been adopted [7,8,13,16]. Due to the significant decreases in the computation time and sufficient accuracy for practical use [18], this network structure allows optimal decisions to be made in MPC. However, in physics-based models, it is somewhat troublesome to define the R (thermal resistance) and C (thermal capacity) of the heat transfer between pipes and the virtual core temperature layer [17,19,20]. In 2015, Wu et al. proposed a new simplified model without a virtual core temperature layer to calculate the surface temperature of radiant floor systems [22]. This model was validated using measured data with the results showing that the maximum differences between the calculated surface temperature and the measured data were 0.3 °C and 0.8 °C for the cooling condition and the heating condition, respectively [22]. In this research, we develop a novel control-oriented thermodynamic model as the internal model of MPC for an RFH system. In this model, the heat transfer along water flow in the pipes and weather elements such as solar radiation and wind are considered, and the new calculating method for the floor surface temperature is adopted. Then an experimental test is conducted to validate the model. In addition, large-scale RFH systems serving multiple occupants in a residential building are common, so the above-mentioned MPC method must be extended to multi-zone buildings. Due to the strong coupling with occupants, the decentralized control mode without a relationship cannot offer good control performances like temperature swings in each zone [23]. Besides, the traditional centralized architecture in which a leadership node must pick up global complete information also faces unprecedented challenges [24]. For instance, the communication delay introduced in issuing dispatch orders causes the local decision-making to be unable to quickly perceive topological perturbations, which fails to achieve rapid reference tracking [24,25]. Moreover, a powerful computation center that is used to cope with intractable computation burden is indispensable for use in system management, which is inextensible and costly [24]. Thus, it is necessary to further investigate distributed MPC (DMPC) for the increasingly complex RFH systems in residential buildings. In the distributed mode, a complicated problem can be decomposed into multiple parallel subproblems with coupling, which greatly lightens the computational burden [23,24]. Furthermore, the extensibility of distributed architecture avoids software updates when new occupants access the RFH systems [25]. Karava et al. presented DMPC for a radiant floor cooling system equipped with localized comfort delivery to optimize the operation of an air-cooled chiller while providing different operative temperature bounds for each radiant floor loop [26]. Soroush et al. applied DMPC for energy resource management systems in radiant floor buildings to better anticipate the effects of disturbances and real-time electric prices [27]. Li et al. investigated coordinated DMPC for a large-scale HVAC system serving multiple zones to allocate energy to meet the operational constraints and energy-saving requirements for central plants [28]. Javier et al. proposed a multi-zone gray-box model for DMPC applied to a multi-zone building with heat exchange between zones [29]. Zheng et al. developed DMPC for the temperature regulation of a four-zone building with mutual thermal influences to improve the optimization performance of the entire system [30]. In the above research, coordinated DMPC was developed to deal with the resource allocation for central equipment [26–28] or thermal coupling between zones [29,30]. However, for heating networks, the hydraulic coupling between any two parallel loops is a more severe nonlinear connection compared with the thermal transfer through internal walls [23]. Especially for a variable flow system, the hydraulic condition not only guides the real-time supply for central equipment but also is closely related to the thermal comfort condition for each zone. Additionally, there has been new research about the supply from central equipment such as circulating pumps or circulating fans in recent years. In 2009, Wang et al. developed a differential pressure (DP) set-point reset strategy for variable speed pumps in a complex air-conditioning system based on terminal valve positions that reflected the occupants’ demand responses (DRs) [31]. After that, Zhao et al. innovatively defined the most unfavorable thermodynamic loop as the branch in which the valve was almost fully opened but the demand still could not be satisfied, which distinguishes itself from the most unfavorable hydraulic loop under operational design conditions [32]. Then a linear rule for the DP set-point reset was proposed and applied in a chilled water system [32,33]. In 2020, Zhao et al. further improved the original linear rule and used it for a static pressure reset in a VAV (variable air volume) air-conditioning system, which produced better control performance and energy-saving potential [34]. These DR-based supply reset strategies could further extend profits from DMPC for RFH systems by communicating with terminals. Therefore, another task of this research is to investigate a DMPC scheme for large-scale RFH systems with hydraulic coupling and thermal coupling, for which a hierarchical optimization strategy is proposed and a novel supply reset rule for central equipment is given, and then to carry out a simulation test to validate this scheme. Therefore, the contributions of this research are threefold: a) We develop a novel control-oriented thermodynamic model for an RFH system based on a new calculating method for the floor surface temperature with consideration of the heat transfer along water flow and weather elements such as solar radiation and wind, and then we conduct an experimental test to validate the model. b) We investigate a DMPC scheme for large-scale RFH systems with hydraulic coupling and thermal coupling, and then we propose a hierarchical optimization strategy to implement the scheme. c) We present a novel supply reset rule for central equipment and carry out a simulation test to compare its control performance with the original. The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 presents an MPC for a single RFH system in which we focus on the novel control-oriented thermodynamic model; Section 3 introduces the DMPC scheme for large-scale RFH systems with hydraulic coupling and thermal coupling, including the hierarchical optimization strategy and novel supply reset rule; Section 4 shows the experimental and simulation validation schemes; Section 5 concentrates on results and discussion; Section 6 gives our conclusions. 2 Model predictive control for a single radiant floor heating system MPC consists of model-based prediction, online optimization and feedback correction. In this section, we focus on the method of establishing the control-oriented thermodynamic model for RFH system. 2.1 Control-oriented thermodynamic model For a heating room with a radiant floor (Fig. 1 ), the total heat transfer process commonly includes the heat transfer along water flow in the pipes; the heat convection on the pipe inner wall; the heat conduction of the pipe wall, filling layer, and surface layer; the heat radiation on the floor surface; the heat convection on the floor surface, internal surface, and external surface of the envelopes; and the heat conduction of the envelopes, which can be described with the thermal network depicted in Fig. 2 . 2.1.1 Modeling assumptions To investigate the thermal dynamic characteristic of the RFH system, the following assumptions are generally used in physical models. a) The heat medium is considered as the homogeneous one-dimensional incompressible fluid with a volume expansion coefficient of zero. b) As compared with the heat convection, both the heat medium conduction along the pipeline and the energy dissipation are relatively weak. Hence, these terms can be neglected. c) The effects of the free heat generated by the heat-dissipating equipment and personnel behaviors on indoor air temperature are rectified using the “feedback correction” link in MPC. The above assumptions have been applied in most literature about dynamic thermal models for their rationality [23,35–38]. 2.1.2 Thermodynamic models For the foregoing heating room, the structure element of its radiant floor embedding heat source and non-transparent envelopes is shown in Fig. 3 . The energy conservation equation of fluid can be written as the following form [23,35]: (1) ρ c d T d t = ∂ ∂ x i ( λ i ∂ T ∂ x i ) + φ + β T d P d t + q wherein, T denotes the fluid temperature; ρ represents the fluid density; c indicates the specific heat of fluid; λ i represents the fluid thermal conductivity; φ denotes the energy dissipation term; β represents the volume expansion coefficient of fluid; P represents the fluid pressure; q denotes the internal heat source term; t and x are time and space coordinates respectively. The above formula can be simplified based on the modeling assumptions. The thermodynamic models of all elements including the heat medium, pipe, radiant floor, indoor air and envelopes can be obtained in turn. Their specific expressions can be seen in Appendix A. It is notable that the heat transfer pattern between pipes and the floor surface is distinct from that in the conventional star-type RC-network model. Besides, unlike the parameter identification to ascertain the values of R and C in the gray-box modeling technique, the thermal resistance for each element needs to be determined based on their physical parameters, motion features and geometry [8,44,45]. The related thermal resistance involved in thermodynamic models is detailed in Appendix B. All thermodynamic models in form of partial differential equations are discretized by replacing time derivatives with difference quotients, and then rearranged as incremental models to reduce or eliminate static errors. Once these formulas are merged and stacked in time series, the water flow vector as control input and the indoor air temperature trajectory as predicted output show an explicit linear relation, which is suitable for implementing optimization [3]. The above control-oriented thermodynamic model considers external thermal disturbances like neighbor room temperature and weather including outdoor air temperature, solar radiation, long-wave radiation and wind, and we employs a new calculating method for the floor surface temperature. 2.2 Online optimization MPC is an online constrained optimization method based on an iterative receding horizon control strategy [6]. Its cost function reflects the desired behavior of a system and serves to stabilize the system. It also works by describing the performance target in HVAC systems, such as the minimization of the energy consumption and the maximization of thermal comfort [23]. In this research, the cost function is defined as the weighted sum of the tracking error and control effort, i.e., the predicted output is hypothesized to be closer to its set-point, and consideration is given to the change of the control input being as small as possible [44]. (5) f i t M P C t = ‖ Q ( T s e t t + 1 − T i t + 1 ) ‖ 2 + ‖ R Δ G w t ‖ 2 = φ T φ (6) φ = [ Q ( T s e t t + 1 − T i t + 1 ) R Δ G w t ] (7) Q ≝ d i a g ( q j ) M × M (8) R ≝ d i a g ( r j ) I × I (9) Δ G w min ≤ Δ G w t ≤ Δ G w max wherein, T s e t t + 1 is the indoor air temperature set-point; Q and R represent the error weighing and control action weighing matrices, elements of which equal 100 and 1 in this work; Δ G w min and Δ G w max represent the bound of water flow. The objective of MPC for RFH system is to minimize the cost function over the prediction horizon and thus determining the optimal input water flow. This open-loop optimization problem is commonly solved with the quadratic programming method [46,47]. However, in Ref. [23], authors have suggested a novel method to deal with this issue that is called a hybrid optimization algorithm, which consists of an improved particle swarm optimization (IPSO) algorithm and the Newton-Raphson (NR) method. The authors have testified that the proposed method can enhance optimization efficiency. 3 Distributed model predictive control for large-scale radiant floor heating systems In the conventional decentralized control mode, the MPC controller of each occupant in the residential building is only in charge of managing its RFH system by perceiving the future weather and desired thermal comfort and does not coordinate with others controllers, which may be the cause of temperature fluctuations (Fig. 4 (a)). Additionally, for large-scale RFH systems, it is common that an automatic DP valve is installed on the main riser whose function is equivalent to a circulating pump [23,48]. Its DP set-point decides the supply to the RFH systems and depends on the operating conditions of a specific occupant such as the outermost occupant that is usually set by default to lie in the most unfavorable hydraulic loop under the conventional strategy, which cannot meet the DRs of all occupants (Fig. 4 (a)). Therefore, this section describes a generalization of the above MPC approach to design a DMPC scheme for large-scale RFH systems with hydraulic coupling (Fig. 4 (b)). First, a simplified hydraulic dynamic model of the large-scale RFH networks is established to ascertain the hydraulic coupling between occupants. Next, we analyze the existing DP set-point reset rules and then present a novel rule. Lastly, a hierarchical optimization algorithm for adapting to DMPC for large-scale RFH systems is designed. 3.1 Hydraulic dynamic model The hydraulic coupling between occupants can be clarified by a hydraulic dynamic model of RFH networks. The hydraulic regime of pipe networks can be described based on graph theory (Fig. 5 ), where its branch flow, pressure drop and hydraulic resistance can be drawn by analogy with branch current, voltage and electric resistance [36,37]. According to the Kirchhoff's law, the net flow rate of each node equals zero, and the algebraic sum of pressure drops of all branches in each loop equals zero [36,37]. These can be represented by the following matrix equations: (10) B k G b r a = 0 (11) C f ( Δ P b r a − H b r a ) = 0 (12) B k = [ b i k ] ( m − 1 ) × n (13) C f = [ c j k ] ( n − m + 1 ) × n wherein, n denotes branch number; m denotes node number; B k is the basic incidence matrix; C f is the independent loop matrix; G b r a and Δ P b r a represent the branch flow array and pressure drop array; H b r a represents the branch pump head array. The term in H b r a is zero unless there is a pump installed in the corresponding branch. For a certain branch k , the pressure drop can be is calculated by the Darcy-Weisbach formula [37]. (14) Δ P b r a , k = 4 ρ w , k L p , k π D w , k 2 ∂ G w , k ∂ t + S k G w , k | G w , k | + ρ w , k g L p , k sin γ k (15) S k = S p , k + S v , k (16) S p , k = 8 ρ w , k π 2 ( D w , k ) 4 ( f k L p , k D w , k ) (17) S v , k = f ( θ v , k ) ( G w , k ) α − 2 wherein, S k , S p , k and S v , k represent the hydraulic impedance, pipe hydraulic impedance and valve hydraulic impedance of the branch k ; L p , k denotes the pipe length of the branch k ; γ k denotes the angle between branch k and horizontal axis; g is the acceleration of gravity; f k denotes the Darcy friction coefficient, which is obtained easily in Refs. [36,37]; f ( θ v , k ) represents the hydraulic characteristics state equation of valve θ v , k attached to branch k ; α is an index varying with the flow state [48]. As can be seen, due to hydraulic coupling, for each occupant in RFH systems, the valve position control command does not only depend on own flow demand, but is also related to the system pump head and other occupants’ flow. And the Newton-Raphson method as a sophisticated means is usually applied to solve the above nonlinear equations. (18) θ v , k t = f ( D P t , G w , j ( j = 1,2 , ⋯ , p ) t ) wherein, D P t represents the DP set-point of RFH systems, namely the supply pressure of automatic DP valve; p denotes occupant number. 3.2 Differential pressure set-point reset rule The optimal DP set-point based on terminal valve positions that embody the DRs of occupants can be enough and just enough for the most heavily loaded occupant, which successfully ensures the overall thermal comfort with the minimum energy consumption [31]. A linear rule for DP set-point reset was initially proposed by Zhao et al. [32]. The strategy can be explained by Fig. 6 (a) and the corresponding formulas are detailed in Appendix D. Compared with the original rule using fixed steps, the linear rule can give a more excellent DP set-point with less time. But, it can be seen that once the deviation occurs, the DP set-point varies certainly, which increases reset frequency. In particular, for large-scale RFH systems, a stable hydraulic condition is also essential. Besides, in this rule, the DP set-point is strictly limited within its bound, without buffering leeway. To overcome the above shortcoming and further improve reset performance, we design a self-adjusting universe fuzzy rule for DP set-point reset, in which the deviation change is also introduced and scale factors are added to the fixed fuzzy rule [49,50]. The strategy is exhibited in Fig. 6 (b) and its rule is specified in Appendix D. From the above strategy, we can conclude that the DP set-point for RFH systems relies on the maximum valve position of occupants, implying that it is indirectly related to all occupant valve positions. (19) D P t = f ( θ max t ) = f ( θ v , j ( j = 1,2 , ⋯ , p ) t ) 3.3 Hierarchical optimization algorithm Due to hydraulic coupling and thermal coupling, any occupant control input and predicted output are interrelated with others in large-scale RFH systems, which is suitable to be handled with a distributed scheme. Therefore, we design a hierarchical optimization algorithm, in which the Nash-optimization algorithm acts as the upper-level scheme and the proposed targeted methods work as the lower-level schemes, to solve it. The upper-level scheme is undertaken by the Nash-optimization algorithm. As a distributed scheme, it is extensively applied in multi-objective optimization [51,52]. Due to the information sharing and cooperation between agents, this method can efficiently improve control performance and guarantee the Nash equilibrium or global optimality [51,52]. It is assumed that the large-scale RFH systems serve p occupants. Consider these occupants and the automatic DP valve as agents. The global optimization objective is to minimize the energy consumption of systems. At time step t , the optimization problem can be described as: (20) Min f i t t t = D P t ∑ k = 1 p G w , k t wherein, f i t t t represents the real-time total performance index of RFH systems optimization. Such a global optimization task involving multi-agents can be decomposed by the Nash-optimization algorithm. For each agent, the local performance index can derive from the above. (21) Min f i t k t = { f i t k t ( D P t ) = f ( θ v , j t ) , k = 0 f i t k t ( G w , k t ) = f ( T s e t , k t + 1 , T i , k t + 1 ) , 1 ≤ k ≤ p f i t k t ( θ v , k t ) = f ( D P t , G w , j t ) , p + 1 ≤ k ≤ 2 p (22) s . t . T i , k t + 1 = f ( T i , k − 1 t + 1 , T i , k + 1 t + 1 , T i , k t , G w , k t , Ψ B t − 1 , Ψ C t − 2 ) wherein, f i t k t represents the real-time local performance index for the k-th agent. It can be seen that the local performance index of each agent is related to others, coupling with each other. For the k-th agent, the Nash optimal solution satisfies the following relation [52,53]. (23) f i t k * ( x 0 N ⋯ x k N ⋯ x 2 p N ) ≤ f i t k t ( x 0 N ⋯ x k − 1 N , x k t , x k + 1 N ⋯ x 2 p N ) wherein, x k N represents the Nash optimal solution of the k-th agent. Each agent cannot change its control decision x k N after the Nash equilibrium is reached, otherwise the local performance index f i t k * will degrade. If the Nash optimal solutions of other agents have been acquired, the local performance index of each agent will be only related to its own control decision [52,53]. (24) f i t k t = min x k t f i t k t | x j N ( j = 0,1 , ⋯ , 2 p | j ≠ k ) To obtain the Nash optimal solution of the k-th agent, the Nash optimal solutions of other agents need to be known in advance, so that the whole system could arrive at Nash equilibrium in the coupling decision process [53]. For the lower-level schemes used to optimize the local performance of each agent, the foregoing description has exhibited them: The self-adjusting universe fuzzy rule aims at giving the optimal DP set-point; The hybrid optimization algorithm works on optimizing the occupant flow; The hydraulic dynamic model cooperating with Newton-Raphson method is used to determine the appropriate valve position. The operation steps of the hierarchical optimization algorithm for large-scale RFH systems can be explained in Fig. 7 , and their description is as follows. Upper-level scheme U1 Initial estimation: At time step instant t , let the iterative index l = 0 and set the accuracy index as esp. Each agents' initial estimation x k l is given and shared. Lower-level schemes L1 Task allocation: Each agent solves its optimization problem independently with corresponding algorithm to obtain an updated solution x k l + 1 . U2 Convergence evaluation: Each agent checks if the given error accuracy is satisfied. If there exists | f i t ( x k l + 1 ) − f i t ( x k l ) | ≤ esp ( k = 1 , 2 , ⋯ , 2 p ) , then terminate the iteration and turn to U3, else let l = l +1, x k l = x k l + 1 and proceed to L1 within the lower-level schemes. U3 Moving horizon: Move horizon to the next time step, that is, t = t +1, and turn to U1. 4 Validation schemes To validate the response of the thermodynamic model for an RFH system to the operating conditions and weather, we conduct an experimental test by monitoring an RFH system and the meteorological data with the Building Management System (BMS). Then the prediction model is transplanted into MPC programs, and a simple co-simulation testbed with the BMS and MATLAB is built to validate the DMPC scheme for large-scale RFH systems. 4.1 Experimental scheme Two interior-separated office spaces that are environmental laboratories with an RFH system and are located at an experimental building in Dalian, China, are used as experimental testbeds for this study. Their 3D (three-dimensional) schematic diagram is shown in Fig. 8 , the sizes of which have been marked in Fig. 8. Both offices have one north-facing exterior wall, and one of the offices also has a south-facing exterior wall with a window-wall ratio equaling 0.25. The office spaces are heated by a water-based RFH system in which water with an inlet temperature of approximately 33 °C flows through pipes embedded in the concrete slab via a splitter and then back to the heat exchanger via a water mixer. In this research, the pipe is made of the polyethylene of raised temperature resistance (PE-RT) and the related parameters can be seen in Table 1 . Except for the indoor temperature T i and floor surface temperature T s , which is the average temperature of five measurement points laid on the surface in a plum-shaped arrangement, the other monitored data including the weather parameters of the outdoor air temperature T o , solar radiation I s and wind velocity V d , as well as the heating parameters of the water flow G w , supplied and the returned water temperature T w , s and T w , r , are recorded using the BMS. All the monitored data were collected from January 25, 2022, at 0:00 a.m., to February 11, 2022, at 10:00 a.m., with a 5-min sampling interval, as shown in Fig. 9 . Additionally, RTD (resistance detector) sensors (±(0.3 + 0.005 | T | )°C) are embedded in the heat exchanger to measure the supply and return water temperatures. For the water flow measurement, a turbine-type flow meter (accuracy class 0.2) is installed between the pipe and the heat exchanger. In addition, thermocouples (T-type, ±0.5 °C) are installed on the desk and stuck to the floor surface to measure the indoor air and concrete slab surface temperatures. A weather station (air temperature, a resolution of 0.1 °C and an accuracy of ±0.2 °C; solar radiation, a resolution of 1 W/m2 and an accuracy of ±5%; and wind velocity, a resolution of 0.1 m/s and an accuracy of ± (0.3 + 0.03 V) m/s) is used to collect the weather parameters and transmit them to the BMS that is configured with SIMATIC WinCC (Windows control center) software framework for the HVAC system supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA). 4.2 Simulation scheme We form a simple co-simulation testbed with the BMS and MATLAB to validate the DMPC scheme for large-scale RFH systems (Fig. 10 ). Once the desired thermal comfort of any occupant or weather changes, the program is triggered. As a core tool, MATLAB first works on analyzing the monitored data from the BMS and feeding back the optimal control inputs based on the prediction model and the optimization algorithms. Then the control signals act on the driver actuators through the BMS to adjust the water flow and reset the DP set-point. With the receding control horizon, the program enters the above segment again. It is assumed that the model mismatch is non-existent, so the feedback correction is neglected. The sampling time of the controller is same to BMS that is a 5-min sampling interval. 5 Results and discussion This section will focus on the verification results of the thermodynamic model for an RFH system and the DMPC scheme for large-scale RFH systems with the experimental and simulation tests. 5.1 Thermodynamic model for a radiant floor heating system The MPC solves an open-loop optimal control problem that relies on the prediction model, so the modelling accuracy has an essential influence on its implementation performance. By imposing the same weather parameters and operating conditions as the experimental test, the indoor air temperature, floor surface temperature and return water temperature are obtained and compared with experimental results, which are presented in Table 2 and Fig. 11 . As can be seen in Fig. 11 and Table 2, the outputs of the thermodynamic model for an RFH system can respond to operating conditions and weather variations including outdoor air temperature, solar radiation and wind. The MAEs between the indoor air, floor surface and return water temperatures of the thermodynamic model and experimental results are about 0.70 °C, 0.55 °C and 0.44 °C, respectively. And their corresponding MASEs are in turn about 0.92 °C, 0.65 °C and 0.55 °C. The established model for RFH system in this work, which considers weather and heat transfer along water flow in the pipes and adopts a new calculating method for the floor surface temperature without a virtual core temperature layer, has great dynamic performance and reliability, as its output errors are within the acceptable range for the practice application. Therefore, the novel thermodynamic model for an RFH system is adequate for the prediction of MPC. 5.2 Model predictive control for a single radiant floor heating system MPC as a state-of-art technique has been sufficiently confirmed that its control performance is superior to the conventional control strategies. In this subsection, we will transplant the developed thermodynamic model for RFH system into MPC and reconfirm its application effect. We preset set-points of indoor air temperature for foregoing testing rooms, where 21.0 °C and 25.0 °C when testing rooms are occupied during the day (7:00 a.m. to 10:59 p.m.), as well as 20.0 °C and 23.0 °C during the night (11:00 p.m. to 6:59 a.m.) are given respectively (Table 3 ), carry out MPC control strategy (Strategy 1) for them. Then the above control performance is compared with that of empirical rules (Strategy 2) like a periodic regulation method of flow for testing room 1 and linear regulation method of flow with the outdoor temperature for testing room 2, as well as that of a classical approach, incremental PID (Strategy 3). From Fig. 12 and Table 4 , we can see that MPC outperforms empirical rules, where control decisions are made only by evaluating current weather. In contrast, due to the large thermal inertia of RFH system, the empirical rules fail to grasp the indoor air temperature within the acceptable comfort range, which results in rooms being overheated or underheated thus wasting more energy or weakening the living experience of occupants. On the other hand, the PID control method is superior to empirical rules, but there are still many failures in regulating the indoor air temperature due to its poor adaption capacity for various operation conditions. Besides, tuning the PID control parameters is cumbersome, and a retuning or auto-tuning approach is time-consuming, which are also common disadvantages of the conventional PID control method. Although there are some overshoot and undershoot phenomena at certain times under MPC strategy due to input constraints and severe disturbances like weather, the prediction guidelines and receding horizon optimization enable the indoor air temperature to substantially track the desired thermal comfort with smaller RMSEs in two testing rooms. In this work, while the excellent capacity of MPC technique compared with other means is not our focus, we are intent to restate its merits and the good applicability of the control-oriented thermodynamic model for RFH system. 5.3 Distributed model predictive control for large-scale radiant floor heating systems For large-scale RFH systems with hydraulic coupling and thermal coupling, the DMPC scheme is launched. In this research, for the sake of clarity, we simplify the residential building into a three-layer building equipped with RFH systems. Then we expand and assume three different operating conditions, in which each occupant possesses the different thermal comfort demand (Table 5 ). A DMPC scheme marked as No.1 for the scene in which MPC for each occupant, self-adjusting universe fuzzy rule for DP set-point reset and a distributed optimization strategy are configured, is carried out in the BMS-MATLAB co-simulation testbed. Besides, for a sharp contrast, we implement simultaneously three traditional schemes: (2) MPC for each occupant, linear rule for DP set-point reset and a distributed optimization strategy; (3) MPC for each occupant, linear rule for DP set-point reset and a decentralized optimization strategy; (4) MPC for each occupant, DP set-point reset rule based on the downstairs occupant's operating conditions and a decentralized optimization strategy. The preset parameters for each scheme in every operating condition are presented in Table 5. As can be seen in Fig. 13 , as DP set-point of RFH systems in scheme 4 is reset based on the operating conditions of the ground-floor occupant, which is the most unfavorable occupant under operational design conditions but does not always represent the most heavily loaded occupant, the decided DP set-point cannot meet whole thermal comfort demands all the time. So, although MPC with consideration of thermal coupling is implemented for each occupant, all occupants are able to gain the desired thermal comfort levels under only condition 3 when the load of occupant 1 is severe in this case (Fig. 13 (a)). As to scheme 3, due to the prior knowledge of the most unfavorable thermodynamic occupant by identifying the maximum valve position in real time, the linear rule can recommend an appropriate DP set-point. But each occupant solves independently own optimal control problem using the lower-level optimization algorithms without communicating and partaking of information with each other. So the indoor air temperature maybe swings on some occasions (RMSE increasing by 0.24 °C in Fig. 13 (b)), which can result in unstable hydraulic conditions, thus frequently resetting the DP set-point (19.7% in Fig. 13 (j)). This also implies that the hydraulic coupling between occupants worsens the whole thermal comfort compared with the thermal coupling that only exists between neighbors. For scheme 1, a distributed optimization strategy, namely hierarchical optimization algorithm, is employed. At each control time-step, the future behaviors of each occupant are shared, so the systemic control decisions can be made from a global perspective. Under every condition, the indoor air temperature is able to track to its set-point without fluctuations (Fig. 13 (c)). Additionally, both the self-adjusting universe fuzzy rule and linear rule for DP set-point reset in schemes 4 and 3 can perceive occupants' DRs to give an optimal set value that is just enough for the most heavily loaded occupant, which successfully ensures the overall thermal comfort with the minimum energy consumption. Although the system energy consumption is least under the DP set-point decided by a specific occupant (Fig. 13 (g) and (j)), the occupants' thermal comfort goals cannot be achieved most of the time (Fig. 13 (a)). That's why their valve positions transcend the optimal valve position domain (85%–95%) nearly half of the time (Fig. 13 (i)). Compared with the linear rule for DP set-point reset, the distribution quantity of valve positions in different ranges in the self-adjusting universe fuzzy rule is roughly the same as that in the former (Fig. 13 (i)) and the energy consumption only increases by 0.8% (Fig. 13 (j)), but the DP set-point reset frequency decreased by 44.6% (Fig. 13 (h) and (j)), which contributes to promote the hydraulic stability of RFH systems and extend the service life of the automatic DP valve. Therefore, the self-adjusting universe fuzzy rule as a compromise choice can serve as the optimal DP set-point reset rule. To sum up, the DMPC scheme composed of MPCs for occupants, the hierarchical optimization algorithm and the self-adjusting universe fuzzy rule for DP set-point reset, can realize the hydraulic decoupling between occupants, thus avoiding the fluctuant room temperatures, and improving the hydraulic stability of RFH systems. 6 Conclusions This research is focused on RFH systems, especially large-scale RFH systems with hydraulic coupling to investigate MPC schemes. Initially, a control-oriented thermodynamic model for an RFH system is established, and an experiment is conducted to validate the model. Next, we test MPC developed based on this thermodynamic model in a single RFH system and expand the MPC to design a DMPC scheme for large-scale RFH systems with hydraulic coupling. A simplified hydraulic dynamic model of the large-scale RFH networks is first established to ascertain the hydraulic coupling between occupants. Then we present an improved DP set-point reset rule to decide an optimal DP set value. Lastly, a hierarchical optimization algorithm is proposed, and a BMS-MATLAB co-simulation testbed is built to implement the DMPC scheme. The following conclusions are drawn: a) A novel control-oriented thermodynamic model for an RFH system is developed in which a new calculating method for the floor surface temperature is adopted to avoid defining the R (thermal resistance) and C (thermal capacity) of the virtual core temperature layer in the star-type RC-network model. The heat transfer along water flow in the pipes and weather elements such as solar radiation and wind are considered. Additionally, the experimental validation indicates that the MAEs of the indoor air floor surface and return water temperatures are approximately 0.70 °C, 0.55 °C and 0.44 °C, respectively, and their corresponding MASEs are in turn approximately 0.92 °C, 0.65 °C and 0.55 °C, which fall within the acceptable range for the practice application. Therefore, the novel thermodynamic model for an RFH system is adequate for the prediction of MPC. b) For large-scale RFH systems with hydraulic coupling, we design a DMPC scheme and focus on a hierarchical optimization algorithm for which the Nash-optimization algorithm acts as the upper-level scheme, and the proposed targeted methods work as the lower-level schemes. Compared with the decentralized optimization strategy, the hierarchical optimization algorithm with a distributed concept can achieve the hydraulic decoupling between occupants by sharing future behaviors, thus avoiding room temperature fluctuations in which the RMSE decreases by 0.24 °C. c) For the conventional strategy where the DP set-point that decides the supply to the RFH systems is reset according to the operating conditions of a specific occupant such as the outermost occupant, we introduce the DP set-point reset rule based on terminal valve positions, and we propose an improved rule called self-adjusting universe fuzzy rule. Compared with the conventional strategy, an optimal DP set-point can be recommended that is just enough for the most heavily loaded occupant, which successfully ensures the overall thermal comfort with minimum energy consumption. Compared with the original linear rule, the improved rule can decrease the reset frequency by 44.6% without more energy consumption, which contributes to promoting the hydraulic stability of RFH systems and extending the service life of the automatic DP valve. In the future, as the complete experiment for the DMPC scheme in HVAC systems is still a gap, we will focus on testing its effects in a real building. coredata.dc:description: Radiant floor heating (RFH) is an advanced technology that can couple with renewable low-temperature sources and improve occupant thermal comfort. However, due to the large thermal inertia, the conventional control strategies based on heuristic rules have difficulty handling a room temperature response to changes in weather or set-points. Because of the excellent coping ability, model predictive control (MPC) has aroused increasing attention as a promising solution to manage RFH. This research is focused on the MPC scheme for RFH systems, especially large-scale RFH systems with hydraulic coupling. First, we develop a novel control-oriented thermodynamic model for an RFH system. A new calculating method for the floor surface temperature is adopted to avoid defining the thermal resistance and thermal capacity of the virtual core temperature layer, and the heat transfer along water flow and weather elements like solar radiation and wind are considered. Then an experiment is conducted to validate that the accuracy can be adequate for the prediction of MPC. Next, we design a distributed MPC scheme for RFH systems with hydraulic coupling. A supply reset rule for central equipment is improved, and a hierarchical optimization algorithm is proposed to implement the distributed MPC scheme. Then a simulation test is carried out with results showing that the scheme can achieve hydraulic decoupling between occupants, thus avoiding room temperature fluctuations and decreasing the root-mean-square error by 0.24 °C. An appropriate supply set-point is recommended that meets thermal comfort demands with minimum energy consumption.
coredata.dc:title: Study of distributed model predictive control for radiant floor heating systems with hydraulic coupling
